Hickinbotham, O.B.E., Political Agent & H.B.M's Consul, Muscat. The Hobble the Political Resident, in the Persian Gulf, BUSHIRS . Sir, I have the honour to re£er1? to my demi-official letter of 22nd August 1939 No.' C/248 and to enclose a copy of a letter No. 320 dated the 23rd August 1939 which I have received from Kis Highness the Sultan. 2. I understand that the Bombay Mint are prepared to undertake the work at His Highness's expense provided permission is granted by the Government of India. 3. I request that the Government of India may be approached and asked to authorise the Bombay Mint to under take the work. Khan Bahadur Ahmed Shubaili will act for His Highness in such transactions as there may be with the Bombay Mint. I have the honour to be. Sir, Your most obedient servant, Captain,I,A., Political Agent & H.B.M 1 s Consul, Muscat.-v Copy in translation of letter No. 320 dated the 23rd August 1939 from His Highness Saiyid Said bin Taimur, Sultan of Muscat and Oman to Captain T. Hickinbotham. O.B.S., His Britannic Majesty^ Consul, Muscat. Reference our conversation with you on the 22nd August 1939 on the subject of minting a new nickel and other sorts of currency at Muscat. I shall be grateful if you will inform our friend the Government of India about our decision for minting a quantity of the new currency v/hich we intend to introduce in the country and request them to issue orders to the Superinte ndent of His Majesty's Mint at Bombay to mint the amount that may be asked for by Khan Bahadur Ahmed Shubaili on our behalf who is now residing in Bombay, and whom we have appointed asr 5 ccMMDsrrm . Memo random No # D-3629-N/39 # / Dated New Delhi, the October 1939 # SUBJECT :- Minting of currency for Muscat State, Reference your memorandum No # G/423, dated the 17th September 1939 # 2 # It has been arranged that the work will be undertaken at the Bombay Mint at suitable charges. His Highness the Sultan of Muscat may kindly be asked to instruct his Bombay representative to get into touch with the Mint Master, Bombay, giving full details of the coinage required. It is presumed that the Muscat State wi supply the metal for the coins # Deputy Secretary to the Government of India. i ^ • iff)'C/jrilfr ^CONFIDENTTAL. -u ^3 Ho No. C/738 of 1939, The Hon'bio the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf presents his compliments to The Political Agent, Muscat, qc and has the honour to transmit to him a copy of the undermentioned documentsfcj^. for necessary action. location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

physicalDescription.extent: Foliation: The foliation sequence is written in pencil, in the top right corner of the recto of each folio. It begins with the first item of correspondence, on number 1, and ends on the last folio of writing, on number 6.

mods.abstract: Correspondence includes a letter from Saiyid Said bin Taimur [Sa‘īd bin Taymūr], Sultan of Muscat and Oman to Captain Tom Hickinbotham, Political Agent Muscat, requesting the minting of a new nickel and other sorts of currency at Muscat. Khan Bahadur Ahmed Shubaili, was appointed as an agent on the matter. Charles Geoffrey Prior, Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, wrote to the Secretary to the Government of India, External Affairs Department, Simla, requesting that the Bombay Mint may be authorised to undertake this work. Correspondents include Captain Tom Hickinbotham; Political Agent and HBM's Consul, Muscat; Charles Geoffrey Prior, Political Resident, Persian Gulf; Saiyid Said bin Taimur [Sa‘īd bin Taymūr], Sultan of Muscat and Oman.
